Our study demonstrates that the conventional views of glacial contraction and interglacial expansion for mesic-adapted species cannot be applied to all the earthâ€™s climatic zones. In East Asia, subtropical avifauna showed narrower distribution and smaller N
e at the LIG and then bounced back to a larger LGM range similar to the current one. The asynchronous range dynamics among organisms in different ecozones might have led to variable evolutionary consequences. For example, at the LGM temperate species might have retreated to isolated refugia facilitating population divergence and speciation [ 1, 65], while subtropical species might have expanded their ranges with increasing gene flow and obscuring differentiation among populations. Therefore, a comprehensive assessment of regional differences is critical to test historical biogeographic hypotheses globally.
